Introduction During the past eight years a variety of interesting and inspiring research activities at the Onderzoekinstituut voor Geschiedenis en Cultuur (Research Institute for History and Culture, OGC) have borne fruit. Notable successes have been achieved during the period under review. It is these research activities that we would like to highlight in particular in this review. Because research is our core business, we have chosen to present the research programmes and their work in the first part of this report, whilst the institute, with its supportive facilities, is discussed in the second part.The reader who is interested in information on organizational matters, which constitute the framework of the actual research, is advised to consult section B first. During the eight years under review, 1997-2004, OGC scholars published significant books with highlyreputed publishers. From the rich crop we would like to mention Hans Bertens’ textbook Literary Theory: the Basics (Routledge 2001), Bart Besamusca and Paul Wackers’ definitive edition in two volumes of Van den vos Reynaerde (Bert Bakker 2002), Albert Blankert’s collection of essays Selected Writings on Dutch Painting (Waanders 2004), Rosi Braidotti’s innovative study Metamorphoses:Towards a Materialist Theory of Becoming (Polity 2002), Jeroen Duindam’s comparative history Vienna and Versailles: the Courts of Europe’s Dynastic Rivals, 1550-1780 (Cambridge UP 2003), the survey by Louis Grijp et al., Een muziekgeschiedenis der Nederlanden (Amsterdam UP 2001), the milestone in the study of Islamic Mysticism edited by Frederick de Jong, Islamic Mysticism Contested.Thirteen Centuries of Controversies and Polemics (Brill 1999), Ann Rigney who happily returned after a 3-years professorship at Vrije Universiteit (Amsterdam) published Imperfect histories: the elusive past and the legacy of historic romanticism (Cornell UP 2001), Jan Luiten van Zanden and Arthur van Riel’s groundbreaking The strictures of inheritance.The Dutch economy in the nineteenth century (Princeton UP 2004), as well as the one-and-a-half `Utrecht’ volumes in the four-volume milestone series Nederlandse cultuur in Europese Context: Joost Kloek,Wijnand Mijnhardt, 1800: Blauwdrukken voor een samenleving, and Jan Bank, Maarten van Buuren, 1900: hoogtij van burgerlijke cultuur, now published as 1800: Blueprints for a National Community and 1900: the Age of Bourgeois Culture (both Palgrave 2004). Perhaps most impressive in terms of impact was the huge study on the Dutch in former Yugoslavia, Srebrenica, een `veilig’ gebied (Boom 2002), with a major contribution by Bob de Graaff.This book toppled the Dutch government in 2002. OGC scholars acquired prestigious grants for their research projects, most notably Josine Blok for her project on Citizenship in Classical Athens, and Koen Ottenheym for a combined project with the Catholic University of Louvain on the architectural relations between the Southern and the Northern Netherlands. Jan Luiten van Zanden was awarded the Spinoza Prize by NWO, allowing him to develop a programme on Economic Development and Inequality in World History. OGC scholars were elected to prestigious posts in the institutions of their chosen fields of expertise. Bart Besamusca became president of the International Arthurian Society in 2002, Frank Kessler became president of DOMITOR, International Association for Research on Early Cinema in 2003, Jan Luiten van Zanden has been secretary-general of the International Economic History Association since 1998. In 2003 Utrecht hosted the first worldwide conference in computer-games research, Level Up, which was organized by Marinka Copier and Joost Raessens. It is therefore fair to say that, during the period under review, OGC scholars were able to continue to make valuable contributions to the rich and fertile fields of Humanities research, specifically within the context of the following Utrecht programmes: 1. A 1. Leadership

With its 20,7 fte this is the largest group within OGC. It consists of 6 full professors, 4 associate professors, 10 assistant professors, 10 Postdocs and 15 PhDstudents.The programme has been coordinated by prof. Mayke de Jong, in close cooperation with other chair holders and senior faculty.The chairs of Ancient History and Medieval Dutch – presently prof. Josine Blok and prof. Paul Wackers – play a prominent role in the project group’s research policy.These three scholars, all with an excellent international reputation, represent particularly strong fields within the project group: early medieval and ancient history, and later medieval Dutch literature respectively. In 2002 prof. Frits van Oostrom was appointed University Professor in Utrecht. Even if he is not a formal member of the programme, it profits from his presence and his good advice. The medievalists have a long tradition of joint teaching as a way of exploring new research topics; such long-term joint teaching ventures have also contributed to the integration of Ancient History into the predominantly medievalist group. Another centripetal force is the Utrecht Centre of Medieval Studies (UCMS), founded in 2000.The Board of UCMS is consciously recruited from the nonprofessorial ranks. UCMS has become the face of Utrecht Medieval Studies abroad, but it also helps to pull together the Utrecht medievalists by organizing internal workshops. A 2. Strategy and policy Broadness, and how to retain it.

Ancient and Medieval Cultures is a lively group, with a broad range re chronology and disciplines. Six chairs participate in the research programme (Ancient History, Medieval History, Medieval Music, Medieval Art, Medieval Latin and Celtic Studies), along with readers in Medieval French and English.When it comes to strategy and policy, retaining this broadness is a top priority.This is also necessary in view of maintaining the quality and attractiveness of the ‘Prestige Master’ in Medieval Studies (‘Prestige Masters’ is a distinction awarded by Utrecht University to Research MA’s with a strong international profile and potential). Legacies, reorientation and the future

The period under review started with the legacy of a successful research programme, which had been envisaged as a pyramid. At its base, there was the essential activity of

making ancient and medieval sources accessible by means of editions and commentaries, of the kind undertaken by dr Hans Teitler (Ancient History), prof. Arpad Orbán (Medieval Latin) and others. In the middle, there was the level of inter pretation of this material within a given social and cultural context, while the top of the pyramid focused on a more specific research area, i.e. the interference between literate and nonliterate modes of communication, and their impact on ancient and medieval societies. In 1996 this research orientation yielded a prestigious NWO ‘Pioneer Project’ by dr Marco Mostert’s on Medieval Literacy (Verschriftelijking), c. 400-c.1100, which by its many activities (conferences, workshops, etcetera) has provided a great stimulus to the entire research group. From questioning the status of written sources within their social and cultural context, the group’s interest turned to the manuscripts themselves, and the way in which separate texts were embedded within these codices.We aim for an approach to manuscripts that does not perceive later and altered text transmissions as a divergence from some kind of ‘original’, but as an integral and worthwhile aspect of the history and impact of this text in a later period.This provides an important focus of Utrecht medievalist research, especially for Wackers, Meens, De Jong, Mostert and a substantial number of postdocs and junior researchers. Similar questions concerning the status of epigraphical and archaeological sources are being asked by ancient historians.The upshot of all this is that the need for advanced teaching in the so-called auxiliary sciences (paleography, codicology, epigraphy, papyrology) is greater than ever before. Such disciplines are no luxury – albeit almost extinct in this country, they are indispensable to advanced research in the older historical periods, and to the creation of an internationally competitive Nachwuchs. Inevitably, such training has to be organized nationally, within the framework of the two national Research Schools in which the Utrecht group actively participates. Blok (with dr A. Lardinois, Radboud University) heads a research group ‘Sacred and Profane in Ancient Greece’ within OIKOS, and she is also a member of the research committee of this national Research School, based in Leiden. During the period under review, De Jong chaired the Board of the Research School of Medieval Studies (based in Groningen); dr Bart Besamusca represents Utrecht in the teaching committee. Utrecht ancient historians and medievalists have made a substantial contribution to special courses and conferences organized for PhD students at the national level. A 3. Processes in research, internal and external collaboration

In years to come, there will be a substantial group of researchers, mostly recruited from history and Dutch literature, that will be interested in the manuscript-based re-evaluation of sources, including the more far-reaching issues of how textual transmission affected the ‘uses of the past’ in a given period or society. In due course this kind of critical manuscript work will also become a self-understood part of any research endeavour, but for the next five years or so, it is important to have this explicitly on the agenda – as was once the case with literacy and orality. Meanwhile, this is not the only spearhead of Utrecht ancient and medieval research to remain important, as will become clear from Blok’s Vici-project on ‘Citizenship on Classical Athens’. Among medievalists, the Arthurian studies remain a central concern.This legacy of prof.Wim Gerritsen, who retired in 2000, is now carried on primarily by Besamusca and dr Frank Brandsma.These literary historians approach the study of literacy differently from the historians, exploring the oral context of their texts’ transmission by means of stylistic analysis.This line of research has proven very productive, also in terms of international acclaim and raising extra research money. Another research strand is dr Erik Kooper’s work on Medieval Chronicles. In the wake of organizing two highly successful international conferences in Utrecht on this topic, in 1996 and 1999, Kooper has become pivotal to an international research network on medieval chronicles. The supervision of research students as well as MA’s and advanced graduates usually means intensive communication among all those involved, professors as well as senior faculty.The group tries to expose its research students to an international field of senior scholars and fellow-juniors who will scrutinize their progress and who will give them informal and pertinent feedback in the course of writing their dissertations. In 1997 De Jong (with dr Walter Pohl,Vienna, and prof. Rosamond McKitterick, Cambridge) founded Texts and Identities in the Early Middle Ages, a training network for research students in early medieval history, with an annual workshop devoted to work in progress, and sessions organized at the Leeds International Medieval Conference. Since 2000 this successful enterprise has been funded by NWO, the Austrian Academy of

The interdisciplinary in the programme really works out, and the researchers are well integrated in international and national networks. Positive is the integration of ancient history researchers, and the unique position of Celtic studies. Medievists of the programme collaborate with medievists in the social-economic programme. Since 1997 the group has been remarkably successful in attracting research funding from non-university sources, especially NWO. During the period under review, this entailed within the prestigious NWO Innovational Research Incentives Schema a VICI stipend (Blok), a VIDI stipend (dr Rob Meens) and four VENI stipends (dr Marike Teeuwen, dr Els Rose, dr Wolfert van Egmond, dr Jose van Aelst). Besides that NWO funded three programmatic research projects, an Aspasia stipend, six Postdocs, and an international exchange project. Members of the group are prominent participants in numerous national and international organizations and institutions in their field of expertise. Blok is on the board of the European Network for the History of Ancient Greece, that she helped to set up, while dr Emily Hemelrijk is editor-in-chief of Lampas, the Dutch journal for Ancient Studies. Brandsma is editor of the Bibliographical Bulletin of the International Arthurian Society, whose president is Besamusca. Kooper is editor of the Series `Medieval Chronicles’, published by Boydell Press in the UK, as well as editor-in-chief of The Medieval Chronicle. He is also president of the International Courtly Literature Society.Wackers is editor of Reinardus:Yearbook of the I.R.S. De Jong is a Corresponding Editor of Early Medieval Europe since 1992, and a Corresponding Fellow of the Royal Historical Society since 1999. She was also a Visiting Fellow Commoner of Trinity College, Cambridge (1998-99); Meens was a Fellow of the Davis Seminar in Princeton (second semester, 1997-98) and a Visiting Professor at the Institut für Mittelalterliche Geschichte in Vienna (first semester, 2001-2). Mostert taught courses at the University of Florence (17-21 February 1997) and at the Central European University at Budapest (27 April - 22 May 1998). An important aspect of the project group’s reputation is the ability of former research students and postdocs to compete in what is increasingly an international job market. Some examples: dr Maaike van der Lugt (cum laude doctorate, 1998) has a tenured teaching appointment at Paris-VII. Dr Albrecht Diem (cum laude doctorate, 2000) held various research appointments, and is presently employed by the Austrian Academy of Sciences. Dr John Nawas (postdoc, 1994-1999) became Professor of Islamic Studies at the Catholic University of Leuven. Dr Mary Garrison, postdoc in the Pioneer Project on literacy, is presently a lecturer at the University ofYork (UK), while her colleage, dr Karl Heidecker, acquired a tenured appointment as a medieval historian in Groningen. During the period under review, the programme hosted numerous international conferences: To name a few: Organizing the Written Word, 1st Utrecht Symposium on Medieval Literacy (1997),Women in the Celtic World: Ideology and Reality (1998), and The Bobbio Missal reconsidered (2001). See for a complete list appendix 2. Project members also organised conferences that met outside Utrecht. E.g.‘Topographies of Power in the Early Middle Ages’ (Bellagio Study Centre, 1998), and ‘Carolingian Legal Culture.The Evidence of Leiden BPL 114 and Paris BNF 4629’ (Leiden UL, 2004). A 5. External validation

Heleen Sancisi-Weerdenburg, professor of Ancient History († 2000), was very active in bringing the fruits of her discipline to the attention of a wider audience.This resulted in numerous publications, lectures for nonacademics, as well as active involvement in the development of new programmes for the teaching of Ancient History at secondary schools. Under her impetus the Ancient historians have also actively participated in Studium Generale programmes, as well as in HOVO, a lecture series for senior citizens. Her successor Blok has continued this tradition.The medievalists were likewise engaged in out-reach activities. Kees Vellekoop, professor of Medieval Music († 2002), was one of the initiators of the highly acclaimed Utrecht Festival of Ancient Music. Utrecht medievalists regularly publish popularizing studies, as well as give lectures for a

Orlanda Lie.With her research group (WEMAL) which recruits most of its membership from outside the university, and her interdisciplinary publications and projects, Lie has managed an impressive continuity and a research endeavour that involves an interesting mixture of academics and dedicated amateurs. A 6. Internal evaluation, analysis, perspectives and expectations for the research programme 1. Strengths

Ancient and Medieval Cultures is carried by an interdisciplinary group of researchers with a tradition of close cooperation.The shared responsibility for the courses in Medieval Studies has contributed very much to its successful functioning.The presence of a wide variety of disciplinary backgrounds among the members is considered of vital importance to the group’s outlook.This is also the foundation for the ongoing discussions, within the group, but also with numerous national and international colleagues, who come to Utrecht to participate in the programme’s many activities.These have now been consolidated in the Utrecht Centre for Medieval Studies, which provides both a platform and a coherent image for Utrecht’s medievalists. Since the medievalist dr Bas van Bavel and his collaborators have become part of the adjacent research programme of Social and Economic History, the social-economic aspect of medieval research is also being covered. 2. Weaknesses

The co-operation of the ancient historians with the more numerous medievalists may seem a weakness, but in fact the exploration of similar research interests proves to be fruitful.The Ancient historians are handicapped by the absence of Classics and Classical Archaeology, whilst at present the medievalists lack a senior Germanist. Furthermore there are impending vacancies for Medieval French, English, Art and Latin. The group expects to be able to fill these vacancies but not always at a professorial level. Especially with regard to Medieval Art and Latin we will strive for the appointment of colleagues sufficiently senior to be able to supervise research students. On the other hand, the Faculty of Arts has supported the project group by the filling of four vacant chairs during the review period: Medieval Dutch Literature (Wackers), Ancient History (Blok), Medieval Music (prof. Karl Kügle) and Celtic Studies (Prof. Peter Schrijver will be appointed November 15, 2005). 3. Opportunities

The newly created Faculty of the Arts and Humanities, which also includes Religious Studies and Philosophy, will provide new opportunities to reinforce existing ties with colleagues in those other disciplines. In particular the area of Ancient Culture is invigorated by the intensified collaboration between Ancient History, Ancient Philosophy and the sections of Old and New Testament in the Theology Department, in the shape of combined teaching in MA-programmes, seminars, conferences and several research projects.The medievalists also intend to make the most of these new possibilities. More generally, the International Prestige Master in Medieval Studies and the VICI-project in Greek History create new platforms for the expansion of the two components of the programme. 4. Threats

The winning formula of the group—i.e. a broad diversity of disciplinary backgrounds well-integrated into a coherent research programme—is threatened by imminent retirements under a tight budgetary regime. Some optimism seems justified as there has been no lack of appreciation or support on the part of OGC or the Faculty of Arts for ancient and medieval research.Young scholars make an extremely important contribution to the programme. It is clear that not all of them can get academic jobs in Utrecht, but it is equally clear that over the period under review, this research group has trained some highly qualified future colleagues in a variety of disciplines.
